snippet.title: Memories of school days flood back
snippet.content: I WENT to Maroochy Primary and Maroochy High. We walked home every afternoon to my parents' shop, Bill's Bait Bar, and spent a good part of my tuckshop money at the corner store on 1c lollies, once a week. Mr Berry, Mrs Logan and Mr Dunk are just a few of the names of teachers I remember. I remember how excited we all got when it was our turn to "ring the bell"! Riding our push bikes around Maroochydore. Narelle Kither I WAS school captain of Tewantin State School's Year 7 in 1986. There was a uniform but it wasn't compulsory (except for photo day). Even shoes were optional, which was a complete culture shock for me, moving up from suburban Sydney in 1981. We used to walk down to the river in Tewantin for swimming lessons where it was sectioned off especially, later moving on to the pool at Noosa High in Cooroy. That was before the Noosa-Cooroy Range road and we would take the very steep and winding old road up, around and around the mountain in the old buses. It took forever. Deciding which high school to send your kids to was easy back in the '80s: Noosa High, Coolum or St John's in Nambour - all there was up this end of the coast. Velesia Page I STARTED at Tewantin in 1974 in Year 7, arriving from Sydney. I couldn't believe how small it was. We used to wear a uniform, if you could afford one, and we travelled to school on Bill Battalina's buses. After Tewantin Primary, I went to Noosa District High and we got the school bus up the old range road. I remember it well because it used to make me sick. I remember one day, Bill Battalina was sick of the kids smoking on the bus so he pulled up at the Timberwah Hall and wouldn't take anyone home until the culprits owned up. It wasn't me but after sitting there for quite some time, myself and a friend said it was us just so we could get going. I thought I wouldn't get in too much trouble but Bill had other plans for me and my friend. The bus finally got going when we got near the bus depot on Gympie Tce and Bill hit the brakes, took us off the bus and made us clean all the buses. Frances Lane (nee McCafferty) More than 700 cast votes for region's most popular vet clinic Miriam Vale sergeant breaks down in court after charge read out.
